world!') hello world! In [ ]: Copied! print ( 'hello world' , 2 + 2 , 'this is python' ) print('hello world',2+2,'this is python') hello world 4 this is python In [ ]: Copied! print ( 'hello world' , 2 + 2 , 'this is python' , sep = '' ) print('hello world',2+2,'this is python',sep='') hello world4this is python In [ ]: Copied! # everything to the right of a # is not run as code, this is called a comment! 2 + 2 # this is adding two plus two # everything to the right of a # is not run as code, this is called a comment! 2+2 # this is adding two plus two Out[ ]: 4 In [ ]: Copied! # we can add strings together! print ( 'hello' + 'world' ) # we can add strings together! print('hello'+'world') helloworld In [ ]: Copied! print ( 'hello ' + ' world' ) print('hello ' + ' world') hello world In [ ]: Copied! print ( 'hello' + 'world' , sep = " " ) print('hello'+'world', sep = " ") helloworld In [ ]: Copied! # print('hello'+5) # print('hello'+5) A mobile store MobiWorld sells different mobile phones to customers. For each order that is placed, the store keeps a record of various attributes related to the mobile, like Price, Brand, RAM (GB), and Internal Storage (GB). Let's learn Python using the context of the store's data. Intro to Variables ¶ First, we have to store our data to a variable that can be used to extract the stored information later. Let's take an example of how we can do that in Python. Q. Suppose the store sold an Apple iPhone (4GB, 128GB) for $900. Store this information in the variables price , brand , ram , and storage . Q&A ¶ In [ ]: Copied! # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # print the value saved in the variable 'price' print ( 'The price of the mobile is $' , price , sep = '' ) # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # print the value saved in the variable 'price' print('The price of the mobile is $',price,sep='') The price of the mobile is $900 In [ ]: Copied! # store the brand name of the mobile in variable 'brand'. brand = 'Apple' # Here we are storying a string # print the value saved in the variable 'brand' print ( 'The brand of the mobile is' , brand ) # store the brand name of the mobile in variable 'brand'. brand = 'Apple' # Here we are storying a string # print the value saved in the variable 'brand' print('The brand of the mobile is',brand) The brand of the mobile is Apple In [ ]: Copied! # store the RAM (in GB) of the mobile in variable 'ram'. ram = 4 # print the value saved in the variable 'ram' print ( 'The RAM of the mobile is' , ram , 'GB' ) # store the RAM (in GB) of the mobile in variable 'ram'. ram = 4 # print the value saved in the variable 'ram' print('The RAM of the mobile is', ram,'GB') The RAM of the mobile is 4 GB In [ ]: Copied! # store the internal storage (in GB) of the mobile in variable 'storage'. storage = 128 # print the value saved in the variable 'Memory' print ( 'The internal storage of the mobile is' , storage , 'GB' ) # store the internal storage (in GB) of the mobile in variable 'storage'. storage = 128 # print the value saved in the variable 'Memory' print('The internal storage of the mobile is', storage, 'GB') The internal storage of the mobile is 128 GB Q. Let's say the store wants to save the information on the billing status of the above phone in a boolean variable. Write the code in Python to implement the same. In [ ]: Copied! # a special type of variable stores just True/False values. This is called a boolean variable. # create a boolean variable 'is_billed' to save the billing information is_billed = True #Note True is in blue. TRUE and False are special type of objects in Pyrtohn print ( is_billed ) # a special type of variable stores just True/False values. This is called a boolean variable. # create a boolean variable 'is_billed' to save the billing information is_billed = True #Note True is in blue. TRUE and False are special type of objects in Pyrtohn print(is_billed) True The value that we store in a variable can be a number or a set of characters or a boolean variable (True/False). For example, a price is a number while the brand name is a set of characters which is also known as a string in python. Whenever we store a value in a variable, Python automatically assigns a data type to that variable based on the value. It also allows us to check the data type of the variable. Q. Check the data type of the variables price , brand , ram , and storage In [ ]: Copied! # check the data-type using the type function type ( price ) # check the data-type using the type function type(price) Out[ ]: int In [ ]: Copied! # check the data-type using the type function type ( brand ) # check the data-type using the type function type(brand) Out[ ]: str In [ ]: Copied! # check the data-type using the type function type ( ram ) # check the data-type using the type function type(ram) Out[ ]: int In [ ]: Copied! # check the data-type using the type function type ( storage ) # check the data-type using the type function type(storage) Out[ ]: int In [ ]: Copied! # check the data-type using the type function type ( is_billed ) # check the data-type using the type function type(is_billed) Out[ ]: bool Q. Let's say a customer buys two Apple iPhones (4GB, 128GB) at a price of $900 each. What will be the total bill that the customer has to pay? In [ ]: Copied! # calcuate the total bill and store it in variable 'bill' bill = price + price # the same result can be achieved by multiplication. bill = price * 2 print ( 'The bill amount is $' , bill , sep = '' ) # calcuate the total bill and store it in variable 'bill' bill = price + price # the same result can be achieved by multiplication. bill = price*2 print('The bill amount is $',bill,sep='') The bill amount is $1800 Q. Let's say the store provides a discount of \$15 dollars on the Apple iPhone (4GB, 128GB) that costs $900. What will be the price of the iPhone after the discount? In [ ]: Copied! # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # store the discount amount in variable 'discount' discount = 15 # calculate the discounted price price_after_discount = price - discount print ( 'The price of the iPhone after the discount is $' , price_after_discount , sep = '' ) # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # store the discount amount in variable 'discount' discount = 15 # calculate the discounted price price_after_discount = price - discount print('The price of the iPhone after the discount is $',price_after_discount,sep='') The price of the iPhone after the discount is $885 Q. Let's say a customer buys two Apple iPhones (4GB, 128GB) and pays a total bill of \$1800. Write the Python code to find the price of an Apple iPhone. In [ ]: Copied! # store the bill (in dollars) of the two mobiles in variable 'bill' bill = 1800 # calculate the price of one mobile price = bill / 2 print ( 'The price of an Apple iPhone is $' , price , sep = '' ) # store the bill (in dollars) of the two mobiles in variable 'bill' bill = 1800 # calculate the price of one mobile price = bill / 2 print('The price of an Apple iPhone is $',price,sep='') The price of an Apple iPhone is $900.0 Q. Let's say a customer buys x numbers of Apple iPhones (4GB, 128GB) for $900 each. The total bill that the customer pays is \$3600. Write the Python code to find the value of x. In [ ]: Copied! # store the bill (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'bill' bill = 3600 # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # calculate the number of iPhones that the customer buys x = bill // price # The // rounds the value to the nearest integer, while / will make it a float # double divided forces the answer to be an integer! print ( 'The customer buys' , x , 'Apple iPhones' ) # store the bill (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'bill' bill = 3600 # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # calculate the number of iPhones that the customer buys x = bill // price # The // rounds the value to the nearest integer, while / will make it a float # double divided forces the answer to be an integer! print('The customer buys', x, 'Apple iPhones') The customer buys 4 Apple iPhones Q. Suppose the store plans to provide a 4.5% discount on the Apple iPhone. What will be the discounted price of the mobile? Type Conversion : The process of converting one data type to another data type is called type conversion. In Python, we can perform two types of type conversion. Implicit Type Conversion - Here, Python automatically converts one data type to another in order to avoid data loss. Explicit Type Conversion - Here, the user can convert the data type of a variable to the required data type by using the in-built functions int(), float(), str(), etc. In [ ]: Copied! # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # calculate the discount amount discount = price * 0.045 # calculate the discounted price discounted_price = price - discount print ( 'The discounted price of the iPhone is ' + str ( discounted_price )) # store the price (in dollars) of the mobile in variable 'price' price = 900 # calculate the discount amount discount = price * 0.045 # calculate the discounted price discounted_price = price - discount print('The discounted price of the iPhone is ' + str(discounted_price)) The discounted price of the iPhone is 859.5 In [ ]: Copied! type ( discounted_price ) type(discounted_price) Out[ ]: float Now, let's check the data type of the variables 'discount' and 'price' In [ ]: Copied! print ( 'The data type of variable price is' , type ( price )) print ( 'The data type of variable discount is' , type ( discount )) print('The data type of variable price is',type(price)) print('The data type of variable discount is',type(discount)) The data type of variable price is <class 'int'> The data type of variable discount is <class 'float'> As we can see, the data type of 'discount' is float as Python is implicitly converting the lower data type to a higher data type to avoid data loss. Suppose we want to add the variables brand , ram , and storage . Will the implicit conversion work? Let's try it! As a list may contain a large number of items in it, there should be a way to access the item that we want. This is achieved by indexing the list to access the required item. Q. Print the third item in the list ram_list. Indexing in list is done by specifying the index inside square brackets. In python, indexing starts with 0. That is, the first item has the index 0, the second has the index 1 and so on. This can be done by using a colon (:) between the start and stop index In [ ]: Copied! # first three items in price_list print ( price_list [ 0 : 3 ]) # first three items in price_list print(price_list[0:3]) [900, 899, 600] Notice that in such an indexing, the output includes the item at the start index (index 0) but excludes the item at the stop index (index 3). The index [0:3] has included the items at indices 0, 1 and 2 In [ ]: Copied! print ( price_list ) print(price_list) [900, 899, 600, 1000] Q. Print the last item in the list brand_list. Tuple ¶ Now that you have learned about lists, you know that data can be modified and altered in a list, making it a mutable data structure. Sometimes, you might want to store data which should not be altered, for example storage. The storage in a mobile phone is in terms of powers of 2, that is, 32 GB, 64 GB, 128 GB, etc. You do not want to alter the number 32 and change it to 30. Q. Store the storage specifications 32/64/128/256 as an immutable variable. In [ ]: Copied! storage = ( 32 , 64 , 128 , 256 ) print ( storage ) storage = (32,64,128,256) print(storage) (32, 64, 128, 256) In [ ]: Copied! type ( storage ) type(storage) Out[ ]: tuple The above data structure structure is called a tuple. A tuple in Python is similar to a list. The difference between the two is that unlike lists we cannot change the elements of a tuple once it is assigned. While list are defined using [ ], tuples are definded using ( ). Indexing in tuple is similar to indexing in lists. Q. Print the second item in the tuple storage In [ ]: Copied! print ( storage [ 1 ]) print(storage[1]) 64 Let's try changing the second item to 60 and see if it works. In [ ]: Copied! # try changing an item in a tuple # storage[1]=60 # try changing an item in a tuple # storage[1]=60 In [ ]: Copied! X = ( 20 , 23 , - 50 , 5.6 , 98 ) print ( X [ 2 : - 1 ]) X = (20,23,-50,5.6,98) print(X[2:-1]) (-50, 5.6) As can be seen from the TypeError, items cannot be altered in a tuple. Dictionary ¶ Lists are great for storing data for a single attribute. But, we might want to add more information about the items in a variable. Suppose the store wants to store the attributes brand, ram, storage, and price in a single variable. Q. Store the attributes of an Apple iPhone (4GB, 128GB) of price of $800 in a single variable. In [ ]: Copied! # creating a dictionary attributes = { 'Brand' : 'Apple' , 'RAM (in GB)' : 4 , 'Storage (in GB)' : 128 , 'Price (in $)' : 800 } print ( attributes ) # creating a dictionary attributes = { 'Brand':'Apple', 'RAM (in GB)':4, 'Storage (in GB)':128, 'Price (in $)':800 } print(attributes) {'Brand': 'Apple', 'RAM (in GB)': 4, 'Storage (in GB)': 128, 'Price (in $)': 800} In [ ]: Copied! type ( attributes ) type(attributes) Out[ ]: dict The above data structure is called a dictionary. Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs. Dictionaries are written with curly brackets {}, and have keys and values. Keys must be unique. Q. Extract the price from the dictionary attributes. In [ ]: Copied! # extract information from dictionary print ( attributes [ 'Price (in $)' ]) # extract information from dictionary print(attributes['Price (in $)']) 800 In [ ]: Copied! attributes [ 'Price (in $)' ] attributes['Price (in $)'] Out[ ]: 800 For the above pair, 'Price (in $)' is the key and 800 is the value. Dictionary items are ordered, changeable, and does not allow duplicates. Q. Change the price in attributes to 900 In [ ]: Copied! attributes [ 'Price (in $)' ] = 900 print ( attributes ) attributes['Price (in $)'] = 900 print(attributes) {'Brand': 'Apple', 'RAM (in GB)': 4, 'Storage (in GB)': 128, 'Price (in $)': 900} Now , that you have learned how to create a dictionary, let's store data for multiple mobile phones in it. The values in a dictionary can also be a list to store information for more than one product. Q. Create a dictionary products for storing the attributes of 4 different mobile phones. In [ ]: Copied! # creating a dictionary for storing data. products = { 'Brand' : brand_list , 'RAM (in GB)' : ram_list , 'Storage (in GB)' : storage_list , 'Price (in $)' : price_list } print ( products ) # creating a dictionary for storing data. products = { 'Brand':brand_list, 'RAM (in GB)':ram_list, 'Storage (in GB)':storage_list, 'Price (in $)':price_list } print(products) {'Brand': ['Apple', 'Samsung', 'LG', 'Motorola'], 'RAM (in GB)': [4, 12, 8, 8], 'Storage (in GB)': [128, 128, 64, 128], 'Price (in $)': [900, 899, 600, 1000]} Using a dictionary, we have stored a lot of information in a single variable. You can buy the Iphone' ) else : print ( 'Sorry! You can buy the Iphone If there are multiple conditions, we may use another conditional statement called if-elif-else statement.
